title: Wecome to PSYCH 420
text:
This is a heading
This is some descriptive text

# This is a comment
# I loaded some packages here. Now these packages are accessible to the rest of the document.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)



If the PDF doesn’t compile…
You may have to install “tinytex.’ Un-comment the two lines below and run them with the green triangle on the right. Then re-comment them.

#install.packages('tinytex')
#tinytex::install_tinytex()



Here is some fake data

a <- 2 # We can use <- to assign values to variables

b <- 1

x <- rnorm(n = 100, mean = 5, sd=1) # Here, I sampled some random values from a normal distribution and assigned them to the variable x

errors <- rnorm(n = 100, mean = 0, sd=1) # Same for the errors

y <- a*x+b + errors # I generated fake y values by using the function y = ax + b

data <- tibble(x = x, y = a*x+b + errors) # I created a dataframe to store the fake data

We can take a peak at the first few rows using the head() functions

head(data) 

# A tibble: 6 × 2
      x     y
  <dbl> <dbl>
1  4.11  8.78
2  6.18 13.0 
3  4.78 11.9 
4  5.21 12.5 
5  6.48 14.4 
6  4.99 11.7 




This is the histogram of x

ggplot(data, aes(x)) + geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.











This is the scatter plot of the raw data

ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_point()










This is a filtered dataset for x < 5

filtered_data <- data %>% filter(x<5)

summary(filtered_data) # We can quickly find some statistics using the summary() function

       x               y         
 Min.   :2.854   Min.   : 5.904  
 1st Qu.:4.209   1st Qu.: 9.053  
 Median :4.347   Median : 9.914  
 Mean   :4.391   Mean   : 9.909  
 3rd Qu.:4.817   3rd Qu.:10.764  
 Max.   :4.988   Max.   :12.661  




This is the scatter plot of the filtered data

filtered_scatter <- ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x,y)) + geom_point()
filtered_scatter










You can add a line of best fit like so

filtered_scatter + geom_abline(slope = a, intercept = b)

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Welcome to PSYCH 420!
What Psychology topics are you most interested in?

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Overview


Intro
Syllubus, and other logistics
Checking R installation

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Hi, I’m Mona


I am a PhD student in Desmond Ong’s lab!
I study emotion reasoning and learning with compuational models.
Driving question: how do cultural differences in emotion cateogires emerge?
Outside of academics, I love dancing and starting random projects! I have ADHD :)

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
How does this course work?


Hybrid format
Online “content modules”

Short videos
Short practice quizes

In-person labs

With TA (me!)
Turn in work at the end of lab
You can leave after you finish

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Syllabus
Download PDF file.

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Expectations


Be engaged

Work in small groups and help each other

Attendence

Attendence will be taken by PollEverywhere questions

You are expected to complete lecture materials before lab

I know that independent work can be challenging
That is why during my office hours, we can come together to watch the videos

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Office hours


Let’s watch the videos together!
It will be chill.
Please feel free to come to office hours to discuss anything you would like, including graduate school, managing ADHD, having a life outside of school, hopes and dreams.













https://www.when2meet.com/?31944050-nWPtY
Please enter your availability by Saturday.

title: Week 1 Lab
text:
Tips


Go to Alex’s office hours! He’s really nice.
For coding, the internet and ChatGPT are your friends










Caution


ChatGPT can be wrong!

RMarkdown Essentials

HeaderR Code ChunkRendering

# This is the YAML Header. Notice it is enclosed in "---"

title: ...
author: ...
date: ...
output: pdf_document
---

print(a)

title: STAT420 Lab
text:
Basic Syntax
# This is a comment. You denote it with #

# This is how you assign values (e.g., 1) to a variable (e.g., a)
a <- 1 

# This is how you create a list. You use the notation c()
x <- c(1,2,3)

title: STAT420 Lab
text:
Packages
# Instaling packages:
install.packages("package_name") # Make sure to include the " "

# Importing packages
library("package_name")

title: STAT420 Lab
text:
Import data
library(tidyverse)

data <- read_csv("data-folder/data.csv")

title: STAT420 Lab
text:
Plot data
library(ggplot2)

# If we want to plot data$y ~ data$x

# Frist, define the data
ggplot(data,aes(x,y)) + 
    geom_point() # add the scatter plot layer
